messages: efe914d7d50a8e4fded00efac4497f03 (02:09): hi, curious, in gvim (windows) when i drag to select w/ mouse, i'm somehow in insert mode. i'd like to be in normal mode so i can yank text that way
efe914d7d50a8e4fded00efac4497f03 (02:13): seems to load by default?
efe914d7d50a8e4fded00efac4497f03 (02:13): so how do i set that var? :)
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (02:13): oh, I mean, what file is loading it?
efe914d7d50a8e4fded00efac4497f03 (02:14): i'd rather just hcange that setting.. gith?
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (02:14): because I never touch any thing in the vim?? dir and I have never had that problem
1c57963323573790df1368cb7c4fc7c6 (02:16): just creating a vimrc will stop mswin.vim getting sourced
efe914d7d50a8e4fded00efac4497f03 (02:16): i already have a vimrc
efe914d7d50a8e4fded00efac4497f03 (02:16): just copied from the default and modified
efe914d7d50a8e4fded00efac4497f03 (02:17): didnt notice mswin.vim was in it
1c57963323573790df1368cb7c4fc7c6 (02:17): if there's no vimrc it uses the example one IIRC
efe914d7d50a8e4fded00efac4497f03 (02:19): when i split a window and load a file in it, it doesn't get the same syntax/indenting behavior as the original
efe914d7d50a8e4fded00efac4497f03 (02:19): well, maybe it does get syntax, but def not indenting and stuff
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (02:21): well, that's pretty much by design
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (02:21): how did you set the indenting?

aca00247070453c27e86f4b3afc8d57f (02:22): I've got a strange problem with vim7 on windows: C-] does not seem to work. ‚ÄéThis is a default installation, where C-] is not mapping to anything else, and the keyboard layout is German -i.e. to type C-] I must do a C-AltGr-]. Any ideas?
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (02:24): if you go into insert mode and press <C-V><C-AltGr-9>, what do you see?
aca00247070453c27e86f4b3afc8d57f (02:26): tpope:  I'm not on my windows machine now, but I seem to remember I either did not get anything or only "]". Does that make sense?
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (02:27): yes marchino, only it's called omnicompletion
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (02:28): dpm: I guess. if that is the case, apparently vim does not know that ctrl-altgr-9 == ctrl-]
aca00247070453c27e86f4b3afc8d57f (02:29): weird. How can I make it aware of it? I mean, I can type a "]" by pressing <AltGr-9>, but <C-AltGr-9> seems not to be recognised
efe914d7d50a8e4fded00efac4497f03 (02:30): tpope: i just have auto indenting stuff for PHP
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (02:30): picasso: HOW did you set the indenting?
efe914d7d50a8e4fded00efac4497f03 (02:31): let me look what i've had to do on other systems
efe914d7d50a8e4fded00efac4497f03 (02:31): does that do it? heh sorry im not sure
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (02:31): dpm: dunno, I'm on a plain old us keyboard
efe914d7d50a8e4fded00efac4497f03 (02:31): it just automatically does some stuff when it loads *.php
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (02:32): and it should automatically load the same stuff for the same kind of file
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (02:32): is your real question how you can change the defaults for php files?
efe914d7d50a8e4fded00efac4497f03 (02:32): it works properly when i initially open a file
efe914d7d50a8e4fded00efac4497f03 (02:32): but if i split the window, and load another php file in one portion of the window, then it doesn't work on the new file
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (02:34): picasso: have you changed anything, in your vimrc or anywhere, that might be affecting this?
85a047d4307a199c9ff8b21f42b02b36 (02:35): tpope: where can i find documentation about omnicompletion and python?
efe914d7d50a8e4fded00efac4497f03 (02:35): i've had it happen in the past, i just figured it was what happened w/ default install
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (02:35): it makes no sense at all that is would est only on the first file that you open
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (02:37): marchino: well I was going to say the help but apparently they left it out
e4dde5fe8a33479706ab83711146acf3 (02:41): how to avoid that vim creates backup files? i already added "set backupdir=./.backup,/tmp
e4dde5fe8a33479706ab83711146acf3 (02:41): set nobackup to the vimrc file without the desired effect
9ac8f3e7bf24caa4faa7b9828e636329 (02:42): okay - gonna give this another shot: http://guruza.com/question/84/reward-10.00
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (02:43): groton: nobackup should do it. try ":set backup?" in vim to see if it is really set or not
e4dde5fe8a33479706ab83711146acf3 (02:45): i guess it is due to the fact that the set nobackup is before two source's commands
e4dde5fe8a33479706ab83711146acf3 (02:46): and then there is a final behave mswin
e4dde5fe8a33479706ab83711146acf3 (02:47): anyway i resolved the issue putting the nobackup command after those two source's commandss
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (02:51): verbose should tell you where it was set
